oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery interviews the Oak Ridge Boys - Part 1
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of the Oak Ridge Boys (performance group) for the Ralph Emery Show. Tape labeled part 1. Tape is recorded in the Oak Ridge Boys' recording studio in Hendersonville, Tennessee. Recording is from December 10, 1992.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Oak Ridge Boys
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ralph Emery recants a story about Jimmy Dean calling George H. W. Bush to talk to Emery -- (01:20) Emery introduces Richard Sterban, Joe Bonsall, Duane Allen, and Steve Sanders of the Oak Ridge Boys, and Emery inquires about how the group arranges themselves on stage -- (05:18) Emery invites the Oak Ridge Boys to reflect on the Stamps-Baxter School of Music -- (07:28) Emery asks Allen about the status of the Stamps-Baxter School of Music -- (09:09) Emery asks about how many members of the Oak Ridge Boys began by singing gospel music; additionally, Emery inquires about the gospel hits that the Oak Ridge Boys had -- (12:47) Allen reflects on his time where he saw the Oak Ridge Boys before he joined them -- (14:23) Emery recalls a New Year's Eve show where he had to run up and down stairs, and the Oak Ridge Boys express the various interesting venues they performed at -- (15:51) Emery invites Bonsall to discuss his marriage and when Sanders decided to get married -- (19:48) Emery questions the number of records that the Oak Ridge Boys recorded with other performers; additionally, Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys focus on Roy Rogers and George Jones' singing styles -- (23:43) Emery asks the Oak Ridge Boys to discuss Allen's personal connection to Bush, and Bush's poor singing -- (27:58) Emery invites Allen to discuss a rally the Oak Ridge Boys performed at for the Bush presidency run, and how the Oak Ridge Boys performed on Air Force One -- (33:55) Bonsall recalls how Bush pulled the Oak Ridge Boys to the side during the congressional picnic -- (37:58) Bonsall and Allen tell about how Bush talked to the Pope while the Oak Ridge Boys were waiting to meet with him -- (42:05) Emery inquires about the singing styling of Bush; additionally, Emery asks about Bush's other country music interests -- (45:50) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys reflect on the perception of famous people -- (49:30) Emery and the Oak Ridge Boys converse about the direction the Oak Ridge Boys are about to take; additionally, Allen reveals that "Easy" had only been performed on overseas television -- (54:35) Emery inquires about the duration of the Oak Ridge Boys success, and Emery inquires about their sustainability -- (55:41) Emery and Bonsall reflect on the major concerns of recording artists -- (1:00:23) Emery reveals he is writing a book, and Emery inquires about the band's willingness to part ways with William Lee Golden
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Oak Ridge Boys;
